data.text: Contents
Introduction

Parenteral Nutrition (PN) is the intravenous administration of a solution containing amino acids, glucose, fat, electrolytes, trace elements and vitamins as treatment for acute or chronic intestinal failure. It is used when it proves impossible to provide adequate nutrition by the gastrointestinal route. PN may also be given in conjunction with enteral and or oral nutrition to meet a patient's nutritional requirements.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
provide guidance on identifying patients at nutritional risk and early identification of patients' requiring PN
minimise clinical risk and promote the safe and appropriate administration of PN to all adult patients
ensure a co-ordinated multi-disciplinary approach to PN within MSE Hospitals Trust
Definitions

table_items.text: A medical or nursing practitioner competent in placement and able to assess other personnel for competence.
A medical or nursing practitioner assessed and competent in CVC placement
A term used to describe an intravenous catheter whose tip lies within one of the large veins. Access to the central veins can be obtained directly or via a peripheral vein.

The administration of PN to a patient with long term intestinal failure (IF) in the home setting. Patients or carers are either trained to self-administer, or nursing care is provided via district nurses or a Homecare Company.

A nurse or Pharmacist who has under gone a period of specified study and passed the criteria to be registered with their governing professional body as a Registered Independent Non-Medical Prescriber. They are allowed to prescribe any licensed or unlicensed medicinal product within their area of expertise.

Non-medical prescriber that works in partnership with an independent prescriber to implement an agreed clinical management plan. Dietitians are able to achieve this status following the completion of the relevant training.

A disorder in which the small intestine is unable to digest and absorb the correct amount of nutrients, or reabsorb fluids, including digestive juices, produced normally by the intestines. It is caused by a number of conditions including post-operative

ileus, Short Bowel Syndrome, Scleroderma, Radiation Enteritis and High Output Stomas. This can lead to problems such as malnutrition, weight loss, diarrhoea and dehydration. Duration of IF can range from short term (1 week plus) to lifelong, dependant on cause.
CVC placed via a peripheral vein with the tip lying within a central vein.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Chief Executive

The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. In this respect, the post holder is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation of this document is available.
Medical Directors' and Consultants
To ensure that all relevant medical staff are aware of this policy and appropriately trained and updated.
Chief Nursing Officer and Directors of Nursing

Are responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all non- medical staff (nurses, midwives and allied health professionals) are able to comply with the contents of this document.
Divisional Clinical Directors

The Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that systems and processes are in place throughout the Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate. In addition, the Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that all medical and dental staff comply with the contents of the document.
Divisional General Managers

The Divisional General Managers are responsible for implementing the systems and processes required throughout the Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate.
Deputy Directors of Nursing (DDoNs), Associate Directors of Nursing (ADoNs), Matrons
Are responsible for ensuring that the policy is disseminated throughout the Division and that the required monitoring and audit are undertaken, with the resources provided to support this.
Clinical Service Unit Clinical Leads/ Unit Managers

Clinical Service Unit Clinical Leads and Unit Managers are responsible for implementing this document in the Clinical Service Unit and for monitoring the impact on the service and reporting compliance with the document. They are accountable to the Divisional Clinical Director and General Manager in this respect.
Lead Nurses

Lead Nurses are responsible for ensuring that all nursing staff (including Nurse Specialists, Practitioners/Advisors) within the Clinical Service Unit comply with the contents of this document and for taking action when this is not the case. The Lead Nurse will make sure that all necessary training is provided.
Medical Staff
The Consultant holds ultimate responsibility for ensuring that all members of the medical team follow this document. To only prescribe within area of competence.
Senior Sisters/Nursing Staff

The Senior Sister/nurse in charge is accountable for the safe care and management of patient on the ward. They are therefore responsible for ensuring that all staff within the ward comply with this document and for implementing a system to provide assurance that this is the case.
Nutrition Support Team (NST)

The NST are responsible for ensuring PN referrals are appropriate. A detailed assessment will be made and recorded in the patient's medical records. Height, weight, Body Mass Index and the details of assessment and estimated nutritional requirements will be documented. The contents of the PN regimen will be documented and each time a change to that regimen is made. The NST will ensure that IV access is appropriate, and complies with the MSE CVC Policy. The NST will advise on and monitor fluid and electrolytes, and prescribe where necessary.
Lead Nurse, Nutrition

Management and co-ordination of the Nutrition Nurses. To ensure the highest possible standards of practice, particularly with regard to the safety of patients and staff against all hazards associated with intravenous nutrition.
Nutrition Nurses
Supporting the Lead Nurse, Nutrition, in providing, the highest possible standards of practice, particularly with regard to the safety of patients and staff against all hazards associated with PN.
To deputise for the Lead Nurse Nutrition Support in their absence.
Nutrition Support Pharmacist
Attend nutrition ward rounds where possible. Order and support prescribing of PN
Nutrition Support Dietitian(s)

Attend multidisciplinary nutrition ward rounds and assess whether parenteral nutrition is indicated, estimating the nutritional requirements of the patient and recommend an appropriate feeding regimen. They provide dietary advice to support a patient moving from parenteral nutrition to enteral nutrition and advise on an appropriate diet which may include nutritional supplements, enteral feeding, or dietary modification.

Registered non-medical and supplementary prescribers within the NST Prescribing PN and other related medicines as an NMP. Each non-medical prescriber is responsible for ensuring they are up to date in their knowledge of the area in which they prescribe, and in the laws pertaining to non-medical prescribing.
PN process
Indications for PN
PN should be considered if:
The GI tract is not functioning and it is anticipated that it will remain non- functional for 5 days or longer e.g. post-operative.
The GI Tract inaccessible
All methods of enteral nutrition have been ruled out.
Complete bowel rest is required
Total nutrient requirements cannot be met through the GI tract alone
This is not an exhaustive list.
Referral
Referral for PN should be made by contacting a member of the Nutrition Support Team (NST), as per local referral method.

Referrals received after 10.00 (Monday to Friday), may not be supplied with PN until the next day, (unless stock PN appropriate) as PN may be ordered from an external company with defined cut-off times for same day delivery.
Referrals for PN Out of Hours should refer to the MSE out of hours PN guideline.
IV access
Route of IV access

Where possible, PN should be administered via a dedicated CVC. This could be a Peripherally Inserted Central Catheter (PICC) or a single lumen CVC. Where a dedicated CVC is not possible, then a ‘virgin' lumen (a lumen that has not been used for anything else) of a multi-lumen CVC must be preserved for PN. All lumens should be treated with a no touch technique, adhering to the Trust CVC High Risk Procedure (NICE 2006).

CVCs should be tunnelled under the skin in patients who are expected to be fed for >30 days (NICE 2006). Placement must be carried out in the absence of infection, to prevent immediate colonisation of the new CVC.
PN can only be given via a peripheral cannula in exceptional circumstances under the management of the NST
Insertion of IV access
The referring team, in discussion with the NST, should arrange appropriate IV access. Wherever possible, a peripherally inserted central catheter, should be used if veins are suitable.
In the situation where PICC is not suitable/possible, a central venous catheter should be placed by an accredited CVC placer, in an appropriate clinical area. Refer as per local method for the site.
Step down from Critical care. If it is unclear if the patient has a functional accessible gut and the use of PN is likely, the CVC should be left in place.
Prescribing PN
The nutrition team will not review patients over weekends and bank holidays, however will make provision for their feeding during these times

The selection of an appropriate PN regimen, including electrolyte content, will be done by the NST. Consideration should be given to refeeding risk (see Refeeding guideline) when devising a PN regimen.

PN will be prescribed where possible by a member of the NST who is a registered Independent/supplementary non-medical prescriber. When there is no NMP available, a Gastroenterology Consultant / Registrar, or the referring team / Critical Care consultant will be asked to prescribe. It is the responsibility of individual clinicians to ensure that they are sufficiently informed of the composition of a PN regimen if asked to prescribe.
Documentation when PN is indicated
Once it has been decided that a patient requires PN it must be clearly documented in the patients' health care records
Why PN is required
What is the aim of PN
How long PN may be required
(Pro-forma attached at Appendix 2)
Supply and Storage of PN

PN will be supplied from Pharmacy in accordance with a named patient prescription to wards, usually on a daily basis. It is to be stored in a medicines grade refrigerator until required. Prior to use, it must be removed from the fridge and brought to room temperature for up to 4 hours. This is to minimise the risk of patients feeling the cold infusion, and to stop large air bubble formation on warming which will make the pump alarm.
Stock bags of PN that have had no additions made can be stored at room temperature.
Please refer to labelling on individual bags to determine storage requirements.
Administration of PN
PN will only be administered by nurses who are competent to do so.
Prior to administration there must be a two person check of the bag against the prescription, by two qualified nurses who have received the appropriate training.
PN must be administered as a continuous infusion via a volumetric pump.

PN must not be disconnected and re-connected due to risk of infection. If an infusion has to be stopped prior to completion any remaining feed must be discarded and the NST informed at the earliest opportunity.
Monitoring
Baseline monitoring of serum electrolytes, liver function tests, bone profile, blood glucose, and coagulation are required before commencing PN or placing elective CVC.
Initial monitoring and monitoring once stable should be according to the following table:

table_items.text: Twice times daily capillary blood glucose. More frequently if required
Not advisable in the acute phase
Daily until risk of disturbance ceased
Daily until risk of disturbance ceased
Daily or as directed by NST

data.text: Refeeding syndrome

If the patient has had little or no nutrition for several days they can develop refeeding syndrome. The syndrome is characterised by hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesaemia, hypokalaemia, hypocalcaemia and fluid shifts, and occurs as a result of micronutrient, electrolyte, vitamin and mineral deficiencies. Criteria for patients at high risk of developing refeeding syndrome, and management of the syndrome are detailed in the MSE Refeeding Syndrome Guideline, available as a controlled document on the intranet.
Transfer of patients receiving PN
Patients should be transferred in accordance with the Trust Transfer policy.
In addition to this, patients receiving PN must be escorted by a registered nurse. This should be a CVC trained nurse to enable any complications to be dealt with immediately.
Transfer between departments on site
PN infusion should be continued during transfer. If any feed is disconnected it must not be reattached and discarded with as appropriate.

If it is necessary to stop the infusion temporarily;(i.e. for a scan) the pump will be switched off, closing the roller clamp on the administration set and clamping the CVC lumen before removing the set from the pump. DO NOT DISCONNECT. When the infusion is to be re-commenced, (on conclusion of the scan), replace the administration set in the pump, unclamp the set and the lumen and re start the pump. It is advisable to check the patient's blood glucose level if the infusion has been interrupted for more than 15 mins. Ideally the rate should be halved for 30 minutes to an hour, to prevent a rebound hypoglycaemia.
Transfer off site
As this is a planned process, the PN should be half rated for at least an hour, then stopped and any remaining PN discarded.
Transition to oral or enteral nutrition

Wherever possible and appropriate the NST will advocate enteral route of administration for nourishment (either by oral intake or enteral tube feeding). The NST dietitian, in conjunction with the ward dietitian where appropriate, will supervise the transition from PN to oral or enteral nutrition. PN would ordinarily continue until 50% of estimated requirements are being taken enterally.
Management of Intestinal Failure

This condition may be adequately managed by modification of diet and fluid intake. Any patients not meeting their nutritional requirements via the enteral route (either by mouth or enteral tube feeding) after appropriate modifications will need referral to the NST for long term PN.
Discharge home with PN
Patients with IF may require long term home PN or fluids. The NST will liaise with tertiary centres on the HPN Framework to arrange review and / or transfer.
Complications of PN
Complications of intravenous catheter insertion
Subclavian or internal jugular placement carries higher risk than peripheral catheter placement.
Arterial puncture, bleeding, pneumothorax and malposition can occur.
Risk of accidental pneumothorax is greater with subclavian insertions compared with internal jugular.

A failed subclavian insertion should be followed by a chest xray for exclusion of a pneumothorax before attempting subclavian placement on the other side. This reduces risk of bilateral pneumothoraces.
Air embolus can also occur with a CVC or a PICC.
If the catheter is in too far, cardiac arrhythmias may occur, if not in far enough there may be large-vein thrombosis.
Occlusive catheter complications
Occlusion of a catheter prevents its use, and the break-up of any solid material can risk embolisation, vein blockage and thrombosis. There are a number of causes:
Mechanical obstruction
Closed clamp
Kink in line
Line tip against vein wall Pharmacological incompatibility
Intravenous nutrition instability
Drug-drug precipitate
Drug-nutrient precipitate
Deposition
Lipid
Thrombosis
In the central veins
In the catheter lumen
At the catheter tip
Metabolic complications
13.3.1 Hyperglycaemia

Most PN regimens contain a high percentage of glucose. Some patients may not be able to manage this high carbohydrate load until they produce enough insulin. For this reason, at least twice daily blood glucose monitoring is required for a least the first 3 days or until the patient is stable. When blood glucose monitoring has stopped, daily urinalysis should be instigated.
13.3.2 Rebound hypoglycaemia

If PN is stopped suddenly, the circulating insulin may result in a rebound hypoglycaemia. To prevent this, planned cessation of PN should be reduced to half rate for at least one hour before stopping.

In a number of situations, this will not be possible e.g. in response to a suspected catheter related sepsis, failed intravenous access, unplanned surgery. In this case careful monitoring of blood glucose is necessary.
13.3.3 Liver dysfunction

PN may cause abnormalities in liver function tests. In the acute setting it is important to determine if changes are due to the PN or not. Other causes include portal bacterial translocation, sepsis, biliary obstruction, unrecognised chronic liver disease or new liver disease (drug reaction, infective hepatitis or liver abscess).
Early changes (<3 weeks) are usually due to fatty liver (due to excess glucose provision) causing a rise in aspartate transaminase, and usually has no effect on liver synthetic function.

Longer term changes tend to be cholestatic and initially cause an increase in alkaline phosphatase, occasionally progressing to increased bilirubin and aspartate transaminase levels and significant impairment of liver synthetic function. This is due to the lipid component of the feed.
13.3.4 Management of liver dysfunction
It is not easy to determine what intervention will have an effect in each patient, and it can take 10-14 days to see any benefit. One or any combination of the options below may be instigated:
Ensure patient is not receiving energy in excess of their requirements (consider kcal from other sources, including Propofol)
Increase relative glucose kcal provision of feed from 50:50 to 70:30
Run PN at a faster rate over shorter time, aiming for 12-16 hour infusion per day
– “Cyclical” feeding
Give lipid containing feed only 2-3 days each week.
Change the lipid source from e.g. Intralipid to SMOFlipid
Infective complications
13.4.1 Catheter related blood stream infections (CRBSI)

CRBSI is one of the commonest complications of PN, and measures must be in place to reduce the risk of this occurring. CRBSI usually occurs as a result of blood-borne bacterial infection following infection of an internal lumen of the feeding catheter from poor aseptic technique during catheter access.
CRBSI causes a number of symptoms:
General clinical deterioration
Rigors
L
Raised pulse rate
Raised respiratory rate
Raised white cell count (occasionally low white cell count)
Raised inflammatory markers e.g. C-reactive protein (CRP)
It is often difficult to know whether sepsis is CVC related or there is another source of infection.
If the patient is obviously septic, various samples will need to be sent for culture and sensitivity, including urine, blood, sputum and wound swabs.
Imaging may also be required to exclude pneumonia or intra-abdominal collections.
If the CVC is a likely source of the infection, cultures will be required from long term lines (i.e. tunnelled / cuffed / PICCs)

For short term / acute lines the line may need to be removed, and there is no reason to take central cultures before removal. Discuss with Consultant Microbiologist. If CVC is to be removed, send the tip for analysis, and take peripheral blood cultures only.
Carefully labelled blood cultures should be taken from each lumen of the CVC, with simultaneous peripheral blood cultures.
If CRBSI is not thought to be the cause of sepsis, the catheter may be used for feeding subject to regular review by the Nutrition Support Team and referring team.
If CRBSI is confirmed in a short term catheter, it should be removed and the tip sent for culture and sensitivity (disinfect the exit site prior to removal).
Ideally, defer placement of a new CVC for at least 24-48 hours after removal of a suspected infected CVC, to minimise risk of infection “seeding” to the new catheter.
13.4.2 Treatment of CRBSI / Catheter salvage in long-term, tunnelled CVCs

In long term, tunnelled CVCs it is often in the patients' best interest to treat the infection and attempt to salvage the catheter. This will always be carried out by the NST in consultation with a Consultant Microbiologist. Until the infecting organism is identified and sensitivities determined, empirical treatment according to the above table should be started, and antibiotics locked in the CVC following infusion.

Certain microorganisms (Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Stenotrophomonas maltophilia and Candida spp) are extremely difficult to eradicate, and could cause ongoing infective complications. In cases of CRBSI due to these organisms salvage will not be attempted unless there are extenuating circumstances.
13.4.3 Exit site infection
Occasionally a catheter may be contaminated during insertion, or a skin infection at the exit site can track down to the blood stream. This can then lead to septicaemia, or a CRBSI.

In order to minimise the incidence of this, all patients with a CVC should have a Biopatch® placed at the exit site. Dressings should be changed weekly, or when loose or soiled, and skin surrounding the exit site cleaned with Chloraprep® (check CVC policy (chlorhexidine 2% with 70% alcohol). See CVC policy for more detail. Symptoms to look out for are localized oozing, pain, tenderness, redness or swelling, in addition to the symptoms of CRBSI.
13.4.4 Tunnel tract infection

When a patient has a tunnelled CVC, there is a risk that any skin infection at the exit site may track down the outside of the CVC, and result in a CRBSI. In order to minimise the incidence of this, all patients with a CVC should have a Biopatch® (check CVC policy) placed at the exit site. Dressings should be changed weekly, or when loose or soiled, and skin surrounding the exit site cleaned with Chloraprep® (chlorhexidine 2% with 70% alcohol). See CVC policy for more detail.
Symptoms to look out for are localized oozing, pain, tenderness, redness or swelling, in addition to the symptoms of CRBSI.
13.4.5 Extravasation of feed
In rare circumstances, a CVC tip may become displaced, resulting in feed being infused into tissue instead of a large vein.
To minimise this risk, the PN care plan must be completed, including observation and measurement of the CVC length every 4 hours (refer to CVC policy).
Training requirements
Competency assessment for management of central venous access devices.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE Nutrition & Hydration Steering Group and Medicines Assurance Group, which are the specialist groups with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the author's responsibility to inform the MSE Nutrition & Hydration Steering Group and Medicines Assurance Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Preliminary Equality Analysis
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 2)
References

H.P. Loveday, J.A. Wilson, R.J. Pratt, M. Golsorkhi, A. Tingle, A. Bak, J. Browne, J. Prieto, M. Appendix : PN Proforma

table_items.text: General information – Parenteral nutrition (PN) is required for those who cannot maintain adequate nutrition orally or enterally. This may be due to Poor/non-functioning bowel To avoid pancreatic stimulation Unable to access the gut via NG/NJ tube route Ensure that the patient is referred to Nutrition Support Team via Inpatient Consultant to Consultant referral form  Explain to the patient the need for PN and that they give consent Out of hours refer to local ‘out of hours provision of PN' Where possible – dedicated lumen preserved for PN  Tip position of the PICC/CVC should be documented at insertion in the medical notes

Daily Care Measure CVC/PICC 4hourly as per CVC policy monitoring for signs of movement, infection, redness If a long term tunnelled, cuffed CVC has been placed, the length can be checked 12 hourly after 2 weeks Check CVC dressing intact and change dressing and biopatch weekly following an aseptic technique  If temp >38.5 report to medical staff and consider stopping IVN Record NEWS QDS until otherwise advised Complete a strict fluid balance  Monitor blood glucose QDS initially. The Nutrition support team will change this to daily urinalysis when suitable Monitor stools / stoma Weekly weights unless requested more frequently Offer regular mouth care  Do not disconnect PN mid feed unless instructed by the Nutrition team or senior doctor NEVER reconnect PN after it has been disconnected If the patient leaves the ward for investigations they should be escorted by a CVC competent registered nurse

Initial: IVN must be checked against the prescription with 2 registered nurses following the IVN policy for ‘Administration of Intravenous Nutrition' Any queries with the prescription can be raised with the nutrition nurse or the on call pharmacist Registered nurses who have completed CVC competency can put up IVN Check the rate and volume programmed into the pump
Community – Home or Care Home: The nutrition team will arrange any discharge with the support of a home care company and/or tertiary centre
